column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Over several thousand years the landscape has been influenced by agriculture .
#Text=In Europe , a broad variety of agricultural landscape types have originated as a result of traditional farming activities and landscape diversity maintenance .
#Text=Such traditional landscapes usually represent the surviving remnants of landscape heritage going back to a remote past .
#Text=They are characterized by a man-made features with irreplaceable ecological , cultural , and historical value .
#Text=A broad range of European agricultural landscape types ( EALs ) represent a specific time-limited pattern of landscapes that express a unique sense or spirit of place .
#Text=They are also cherished due to their biological or anthropogenic values .
#Text=The massive socioeconomic changes of the twentieth century caused serious loss of unique rural ecosystem habitats .
#Text=Agriculture has become oriented towards maximum profit , requiring strict specialization of agricultural production .
#Text=Specialized agricultural systems brought higher economic income for farmers .

#Text=On the other hand , typical EALs with mixed farming structures bearing historically- , culturally- , and regionally-specific characteristics have become rare and , in many regions , have disappeared .
#Text=In the European Eastern Bloc countries , EALs were influenced by collectivization or land consolidation , mostly for arable and pastoral landscapes .
#Text=The more marginal ones in the mountains changed less , and traditional land use forms have persisted to date .

#Text=In Central Europe , traditional farming practices have been significantly influenced by current innovative technologies , intensification of agriculture , industry , transport development , and collectivization .

#Text=The present-day character of the agricultural landscape in Europe has been significantly influenced by several processes but in a number of places a dominant rural character remains , delivering cultural , recreational , habitat , and supporting services
#Text=Despite the above-mentioned exceptional value of the historical rural landscape , its conservation practice is very poor .
#Text=The unique features of EALs are becoming rare and more valuable .
#Text=Considering the disappearance and ongoing abandonment of historical rural landscapes in Europe , the preservation of these landscapes is an issue of growing importance .
#Text=Multifunctional and sustainable farming activities emerged as a concept that contributes to the preservation of rural landscape 's heritage .
#Text=Multifunctionality is one of the most important aspects of sustainable rural development .
#Text=In the scientific literature there is no generally accepted understanding of the essence of multifunctionality .
#Text=There are essentially two approaches .
#Text=The first one interprets multifunctionality as a characteristic of an economic activity .
#Text=The second one refers to the multiple roles assigned to agriculture .

#Text=Even the most commonly cited definition , the working definition of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development ( 2001 ) , does not reflect the essence of the phenomenon , but rather its two main characteristics .
#Text=According to this definition , “ the key elements of multifunctionality are the existence of numerous market and non-market results that are jointly produced in agriculture ” .
#Text=Rural identity expressed in the knowledge and perception of both local land users and rural entrepreneurs plays a crucial role in historical EAL maintenance and sustainable rural development .
#Text=Raising awareness on landscape values for farmers and stakeholders should improve the quality of landscape and bring added value to the landscape .
#Text=The concept of multifunctional and sustainable farming should be disseminated and should become a philosophy for product trademark .
#Text=The main problem is weak knowledge of people living in a territory with respect to a particular EAL .
#Text=Residents , including farmers and other inhabitants , usually underestimate cultural , historical , and environmental value .
#Text=Moreover , they have no idea of how to implement landscape values into their farm business plans .

#Text=Due to the lack of EAL maintenance , preservation status , and farmer awareness of landscape values we aimed to deliver comprehensive research findings on the relationship between multifunctional and/or sustainable farming practices of small farms and EALs particularly embedding traditional features in land use .

#Text=The FEAL project ( FEAL : multifunctional Farming for the sustainability of European Agricultural Landscapes ) aimed at the development of online vocational and educational training material ( VET ) for small , family , and young farmers living in the rural environment .
#Text=The training material explained how to apply knowledge on landscape values in different landscape types and to implement it into daily farming activities through case studies .
#Text=Further , it clarified how multifunctional and sustainable farming practices aiming at protecting the heritage of European agricultural landscapes lead to win – win situations .
#Text=The FEAL research was grounded in material collected from farmers/promoters of good practices through questionnaires .
#Text=The article 's objective was to evaluate data gathered from case studies of the FEAL project .

#Text=We evaluated the frequency of farm locations within coordination of information on the environment ( CORINE ) 2012 Land Cover ( CLC ) classes with traditional land use forms , nature and landscape protection areas/ecologically important areas , and High Nature Value ( HNV ) farmland .
#Text=Attitudes of farmers to the multifunctional and sustainable agriculture mirrored in key words which were selected by the farmers and collected during a questionnaire survey .
#Text=The presence of key words within CLC 2012 classes with traditional land use forms documented preferences of farmers characterizing a certain land cover class .
#Text=Results interpreted positive external effects of farms on values of European agricultural landscapes .
